france.fun_fact: France is the most visited country in the world.
france.history: France has a rich history that includes the reign of the Merovingians, Carolingians, and Capetians, leading to the establishment of the French Republic in 1792.

Eiffel Tower.description: An iconic symbol of France, the Eiffel Tower is a wrought-iron lattice tower on the Champ de Mars in Paris.

Louvre Museum.description: The world's largest art museum and a historic monument in Paris, France.

Palace of Versailles.description: A former royal residence located just outside Paris, known for its opulent architecture and gardens.

Croissant.description: A buttery, flaky pastry named for its crescent shape, often enjoyed at breakfast.

Baguette.description: A long, thin loaf of French bread known for its crispy crust and soft interior.

Ratatouille.description: A traditional Provençal vegetable dish made with zucchini, eggplant, peppers, and tomatoes.

Crêpes.description: Thin pancakes that can be filled with sweet or savory ingredients, popular throughout France.

Coq au Vin.description: A classic French dish of chicken braised with wine, lardons, mushrooms, and garlic.

Paris Métro.description: The Paris Métro is a rapid transit system that serves the city of Paris and its suburbs, known for its efficiency and extensive network.

TGV.description: The TGV (Train à Grande Vitesse) is France's high-speed train service, connecting major cities across the country.

Tramway de Nice.description: A modern tram system in Nice that provides convenient transportation along the French Riviera.

Bastille Day.description: France's national day, commemorating the storming of the Bastille prison in 1789, celebrated with fireworks and parades.

Cannes Film Festival.description: An annual film festival held in Cannes, showcasing new films of all genres from around the world.

Fête de la Musique.description: A music celebration held annually on the summer solstice, featuring free concerts across the country.

japan.history: Japan's history spans thousands of years, from the Jomon period (14,000–300 BCE) through the Heian period (794–1185) and into the modern era with the Meiji Restoration in 1868.

Mount Fuji.description: Japan’s tallest mountain and an iconic symbol, popular for climbing and scenic views.

Fushimi Inari Taisha.description: Famous for its thousands of vermilion torii gates leading up the sacred Mount Inari.

Tokyo Skytree.description: The tallest structure in Japan, offering panoramic views of the city from its observation decks.

Sushi.description: A traditional Japanese dish consisting of vinegared rice accompanied by various ingredients, including seafood and vegetables.

Ramen.description: A popular noodle soup dish that comes in various styles, often topped with meat, vegetables, and a boiled egg.

Tempura.description: Battered and deep-fried seafood or vegetables, served with a dipping sauce.

Okonomiyaki.description: A savory pancake filled with a variety of ingredients, including cabbage, meat, and seafood.

Matcha.description: A finely ground powder of specially grown green tea leaves, used in traditional Japanese tea ceremonies.

Tokyo Metro.description: A vast and efficient subway system serving Tokyo and its suburbs, known for its punctuality and cleanliness.

Shinkansen.description: Japan's high-speed rail network, connecting major cities with trains that can travel up to 320 km/h (200 mph).

Osaka Metro.description: The subway system in Osaka, providing convenient access to the city's attractions and neighborhoods.

Cherry Blossom Festival.description: A celebration of the blooming of cherry blossoms, with festivals and picnics held in parks across Japan.

Gion Matsuri.description: Kyoto's most famous festival, featuring parades of floats and traditional performances.

Tanabata Festival.description: A star festival celebrating the meeting of two celestial lovers, with colorful decorations and wishes written on tanzaku (small pieces of paper).

brazil.fun_fact: Brazil is the largest country in South America.
brazil.history: Brazil was a Portuguese colony from 1500 until it gained independence in 1822, becoming a republic in 1889.

Christ the Redeemer.description: An iconic statue of Jesus Christ overlooking the city.

Amazon Rainforest.description: The largest rainforest in the world, home to diverse wildlife.

Iguazu Falls.description: A massive waterfall system on the border of Brazil and Argentina.

Feijoada.description: A traditional Brazilian stew made with black beans and various cuts of pork, often served with rice.

Pão de Queijo.description: Cheese bread rolls made from tapioca flour, popular as a snack or breakfast item.

Brigadeiro.description: A chocolate truffle made with condensed milk, cocoa powder, butter, and chocolate sprinkles.

Coxinha.description: A popular street food snack made of shredded chicken wrapped in dough and deep-fried.

Açaí Bowl.description: A smoothie bowl made from açaí berries, often topped with granola, fruits, and honey.

São Paulo Metro.description: A comprehensive metro system serving São Paulo, known for its extensive network and efficiency.

Rio de Janeiro Light Rail.description: A modern light rail system that connects key areas of Rio de Janeiro, including the city center and tourist attractions.

Belo Horizonte Bus Rapid Transit.description: A bus rapid transit system in Belo Horizonte, providing fast and reliable public transportation.

Carnival.description: A world-famous festival featuring parades, samba music, and vibrant costumes, celebrated across Brazil.

Festa Junina.description: A traditional Brazilian festival celebrating rural life with bonfires, dances, and typical foods.

Parintins Folklore Festival.description: An annual festival in the Amazon region celebrating local folklore with music, dance, and theatrical performances.

canada.fun_fact: Canada has the longest coastline of any country in the world.
canada.history: Canada was originally inhabited by Indigenous peoples, later explored by Europeans in the 15th century, and became a self-governing dominion in 1867.

Niagara Falls.description: A world-famous waterfall located on the border between Canada and the United States, known for its stunning beauty and power.

Banff National Park.description: Canada's oldest national park, famous for its mountainous terrain, glaciers, and turquoise lakes.

CN Tower.description: A 553-meter-high concrete communications and observation tower, one of the tallest in the world.

Poutine.description: A Canadian dish consisting of fries topped with cheese curds and gravy.

Butter Tarts.description: A sweet pastry filled with a mixture of butter, sugar, and eggs.

Nanaimo Bars.description: A no-bake dessert bar originating from Nanaimo, British Columbia, with a crumbly base, custard-flavored icing, and chocolate topping.

Toronto Transit Commission (TTC).description: The public transit system serving Toronto, including subways, streetcars, and buses.

Vancouver SkyTrain.description: A rapid transit system in Metro Vancouver, known for its efficiency and scenic views.

Montreal Metro.description: A comprehensive subway system serving the city of Montreal, known for its unique art and architecture.

Toronto International Film Festival.description: One of the largest publicly attended film festivals in the world, showcasing new films from around the globe.

Canada Day.description: Canada's national day, celebrated with fireworks, concerts, and parades across the country.

Montreal Jazz Festival.description: The largest jazz festival in the world, featuring thousands of artists from dozens of countries.

australia.fun_fact: Australia is home to the world's longest fence, known as the Dingo Fence.
australia.history: Australia was inhabited by Indigenous Australians for over 65,000 years before British colonization began in 1788, leading to the establishment of the Commonwealth of Australia in 1901.

Sydney Opera House.description: A world-famous performing arts center and architectural icon.

Great Barrier Reef.description: The world's largest coral reef system, renowned for its marine biodiversity.

Uluru (Ayers Rock).description: A massive sandstone monolith and sacred Aboriginal site.

Vegemite.description: A savory spread made from yeast extract, popular on toast.

Lamington.description: A sponge cake coated in chocolate and coconut.

Meat Pie.description: A hand-sized pie filled with minced meat and gravy.

Sydney Trains.description: A suburban rail network serving the Sydney metropolitan area.

Melbourne Tram.description: The largest urban tramway network in the world, serving Melbourne.

Transperth.description: Public transport system in Perth, including trains, buses, and ferries.

Sydney Festival.description: An annual arts festival featuring music, theater, and dance performances.

Melbourne Cup.description: Australia's most famous horse race, known as 'the race that stops a nation.'

Vivid Sydney.description: A festival of light, music, and ideas, featuring outdoor immersive light installations.

spain.fun_fact: Spain is the second most spoken language in the world.
spain.history: Spain's history includes the Iberian Peninsula's early inhabitants, the Roman Empire, the Moorish occupation, and the unification of Spain under the Catholic Monarchs in 1492.

Sagrada Família.description: A large unfinished Roman Catholic basilica designed by Antoni Gaudí.

Alhambra.description: A palace and fortress complex of the Moorish monarchs of Granada.

Park Güell.description: A public park system composed of gardens and architectonic elements designed by Gaudí.

Paella.description: A rice dish originally from Valencia, made with seafood, meat, and vegetables.

Tapas.description: Small savory dishes, snacks, or appetizers, typical in Spanish cuisine.

Churros.description: Fried-dough pastry, often served with hot chocolate.

Madrid Metro.description: The rapid transit system serving Madrid and its metropolitan area.

Barcelona Metro.description: A large metro network serving the city of Barcelona.

Renfe.description: Spain's national railway company, operating both commuter and long-distance trains.

La Tomatina.description: A festival held in Buñol where participants throw tomatoes at each other.

Running of the Bulls.description: A part of the San Fermín festival in Pamplona, featuring the running of bulls through the streets.

Semana Santa.description: Holy Week, celebrated with elaborate processions throughout Spain.

italy.fun_fact: Italy has more UNESCO World Heritage sites than any other country.
italy.history: Italy's history includes the Roman Empire, the Renaissance, and the unification of Italy in the 19th century.

Colosseum.description: An ancient Roman gladiatorial arena and one of the most iconic landmarks in Italy.

Leaning Tower of Pisa.description: A world-famous freestanding bell tower known for its unintended tilt.

Venice Canals.description: A network of picturesque canals that wind through the historic city of Venice.

Pizza Margherita.description: A classic Neapolitan pizza topped with tomatoes, mozzarella, and basil.

Pasta Carbonara.description: A Roman pasta dish made with eggs, cheese, pancetta, and pepper.

Gelato.description: Italian-style ice cream, known for its rich flavor and smooth texture.

Rome Metro.description: The rapid transit system serving Rome.

Milan Metro.description: The largest metro system in Italy, serving Milan.

Trenitalia.description: Italy's primary train operator, providing high-speed and regional rail services.

Venice Carnival.description: A world-famous festival held in Venice, known for its elaborate masks and costumes.

Palio di Siena.description: A historic horse race held twice each summer in Siena.

Milan Fashion Week.description: A major event in the international fashion calendar, held twice a year in Milan.

india.fun_fact: India is the world's largest democracy.
india.history: India's history includes the Indus Valley Civilization, Mughal Empire, British colonial rule, and independence in 1947.

Taj Mahal.description: A white marble mausoleum and UNESCO World Heritage site, considered one of the New Seven Wonders of the World.

Jaipur City Palace.description: A historic palace complex that blends Rajasthani and Mughal architecture.

Gateway of India.description: A monumental archway built during the 20th century in Mumbai, overlooking the Arabian Sea.

Biryani.description: A flavorful rice dish made with spices, rice, and meat or vegetables.

Masala Dosa.description: A thin, crispy pancake made from fermented rice and lentil batter, filled with spiced potatoes.

Butter Chicken.description: A popular North Indian dish of chicken in a mildly spiced tomato sauce.

Delhi Metro.description: A rapid transit system serving Delhi and its satellite cities.

Mumbai Suburban Railway.description: A suburban rail system serving Mumbai and its metropolitan region.

Kolkata Metro.description: India's first underground metro system, serving Kolkata.

Diwali.description: The Hindu festival of lights, celebrated with lamps, fireworks, and sweets.

Holi.description: The festival of colors, celebrated with vibrant powders and water.

Durga Puja.description: A major Hindu festival in West Bengal, celebrating the goddess Durga.

panama.fun_fact: Panama is home to the Panama Canal, a key conduit for international maritime trade.
panama.history: Panama was part of Colombia until it gained independence in 1903, with the canal opening in 1914.

Panama Canal.description: A man-made waterway connecting the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.

San Blas Islands.description: An archipelago of over 350 islands known for their beauty and indigenous culture.

Casco Viejo.description: The historic district of Panama City, known for its colonial-era landmarks.

Sancocho.description: A traditional chicken and vegetable stew, considered Panama's national dish.

Ceviche.description: Seafood marinated in citrus juices, often served as an appetizer.

Arroz con Pollo.description: A popular dish of rice cooked with chicken and vegetables.

Metro de Panamá.description: The first rapid transit system in Central America, serving Panama City.

MiBus.description: The main bus system in Panama City, providing urban and suburban service.

Albrook Bus Terminal.description: The largest bus terminal in Panama, connecting the city with the rest of the country.

Carnaval de Panamá.description: A lively festival with parades, music, and dancing, celebrated before Lent.

Festival de la Mejorana.description: A traditional folk festival held in Guararé, featuring music, dance, and crafts.

Semana Santa.description: Holy Week, celebrated with religious processions and events throughout Panama.

mexico.fun_fact: Mexico introduced chocolate, chilies, and corn to the world.
mexico.history: Mexico is home to ancient civilizations such as the Maya and Aztecs, was colonized by Spain in the 16th century, and gained independence in 1821.

Chichen Itza.description: A large pre-Columbian archaeological site built by the Maya civilization.

Teotihuacan.description: An ancient Mesoamerican city known for its massive pyramids.

Cabo San Lucas.description: A resort city known for its beaches, marine life, and nightlife.

Tacos.description: A traditional Mexican dish consisting of small hand-sized corn or wheat tortillas topped with a filling.

Mole.description: A rich sauce made with chili peppers, spices, and chocolate, often served over chicken.

Tamales.description: A traditional dish made of masa (corn dough) filled with meats, cheeses, or chilies, wrapped in corn husks and steamed.

Mexico City Metro.description: One of the largest and busiest metro systems in the world, serving Mexico City.

Metrobus.description: A bus rapid transit system operating in Mexico City.

Guadalajara Light Rail.description: A light rail system serving the city of Guadalajara.

Día de los Muertos.description: The Day of the Dead, a celebration honoring deceased loved ones with altars, offerings, and festivities.

Guelaguetza.description: An annual indigenous cultural event in Oaxaca featuring traditional dances, music, and costumes.

Cinco de Mayo.description: A holiday commemorating the Mexican victory over the French at the Battle of Puebla in 1862.

germany.fun_fact: Germany is home to the world's oldest zoo, the Berlin Zoo, founded in 1844.
germany.history: Germany's history includes the Holy Roman Empire, the Reformation, the unification in 1871, and the division during the Cold War, leading to reunification in 1990.

Brandenburg Gate.description: An iconic neoclassical monument that has become a symbol of Berlin and Germany.

Neuschwanstein Castle.description: A fairy-tale castle built by King Ludwig II, known for its picturesque setting.

Cologne Cathedral.description: A Gothic cathedral and UNESCO World Heritage site, famous for its twin spires.

Bratwurst.description: A type of German sausage made from pork, beef, or veal.

Sauerkraut.description: Fermented cabbage, often served as a side dish with meats.

Pretzel (Brezel).description: A baked bread product, typically twisted into a knot shape and sprinkled with coarse salt.

Berlin U-Bahn.description: The rapid transit system serving Berlin, known for its extensive network.

Munich U-Bahn.description: The subway system serving Munich, providing efficient transportation across the city.

Deutsche Bahn (DB).description: Germany's national railway company, operating high-speed and regional trains.

Oktoberfest.description: The world's largest beer festival held annually in Munich, celebrating Bavarian culture with beer, food, and music.

Berlin International Film Festival (Berl.description: One of the most prestigious film festivals in the world, showcasing international films.

Christmas Markets.description: Traditional markets held throughout Germany, featuring festive decorations, food, and handmade crafts.
